Key Match Events: India won by 8 wickets (with 46 balls remaining)
Pre-Game Insights: India have won all seven completed T20Is against Ireland so far
India played two high-profile games at the last T20 World Cup. They won the one where the pitch was tough to bat on and lost the one where it was considerably easier.
Josh Little will be asked to do what other left-arm quicks have done against India in the past. Bowl full and try to get lbws and bowleds.
Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli and Suryakumar Yadav - their three best batters - are likely to be Nos. 1, 2 and 3.
Jasprit Bumrah holding his length back and prioritising being unhittable first.
Paul Stirling to respond with calculated risks to maximise the powerplay.
Kuldeep Yadav will make the most of his improved air speed by never giving up the stumps.
All of Ireland - particularly their middle order of Harry Tector and Curtis Campher - will have to work together to deny him wickets.
India WWWWL (last five completed T20Is, most recent first)
Rishabh Pant is all set to make his comeback for India
Harry Tector made his highest T20I score against India, an action-packed 64 off 33 balls.
Shivam Dube is likely to slot into the middle order and take on the spinners.
India's bowling contains plenty of variety but it is centered around Bumrah and Kuldeep.
Ireland's batting goes down to No. 8 and it has a reasonable split between power-hitters and shock absorbers.
Andy Balbirnie and Lorcan Tucker have the ability to do both of those roles.
Their bowling is seam-dominated but left-arm spinner George Dockrell could get an over or two against the more orthodox batters in the Indian line-up.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The weather in New York is perfect for cricket. Not too hot, not too cold, no worry about dew.
The pitch and outfield, however, will be under the scanner again after the events from Monday, where 80 for 4 in 16.2 overs played 77 all out.
India played a warm-up game here, on a different track, and they scored 180.
Kohli averages 81.5 in T20 World Cups having turned 14 of his 25 innings into 50-plus scores.
Bumrah has taken six wickets in 12 overs against Ireland at an average of 9.66 and economy rate of 4.83.
India have won all seven completed T20Is between the two teams.
India coach Rahul Dravid is hopeful the game will acquire a new market.
Ireland's George Dockrell is hoping for some support on Wednesday.
